questions.question: What property allows a logical operator to express all Boolean functions?
questions.explanation: Functionally complete sets of operators can generate all possible Boolean operations.

questions.question: What is the Sheffer stroke?
questions.explanation: Sheffer stroke is another name for NAND.

questions.question: What is the Peirce arrow?
questions.explanation: Peirce arrow is another name for NOR.

questions.question: What is the classical truth-functional if-then operator called?
questions.explanation: Material implication is the standard truth-functional conditional in classical logic.

questions.question: What is the biconditional operator also called?
questions.explanation: Material equivalence is the operator for logical equivalence (if and only if).

questions.question: What operator is the dual of AND?
What principle relates implication to disjunction?
questions.explanation: Implication can be expressed as OR.

questions.question: What is the absorption law for AND?
What set of operators is functionally complete?
questions.explanation: AND with NOT generates all operations.

questions.question: What is the key difference between XOR and inclusive OR?
questions.answer: XOR is false when both true
questions.explanation: XOR is exclusive (true when exactly one operand is true), while OR is inclusive.
